title: About
text:
The InforBio platform has developed an ‚ÄúInteractive Online Companionship‚Äù (IOC) specifically tailored to initiate researchers into bioinformatics. The IOC involved one-to-many virtual work sessions where companions are trained to analyze their own data.
All IOC programs are structured into a series of modules, with each module building upon the knowledge and skills acquired in the previous one. One module lasts one week, during which companions dive into online materials to ensure they understand and internalize the content. Companions then complete quizzes and exercises using both public and their own data to gauge their understanding, receiving personalized feedback on their work. To facilitate their learning, we provide access to computational resources such as Rstudio and Galaxy servers. The module wraps up with a 2.5 hours‚Äô videoconference to recap the week‚Äôs material and address any questions. These videoconferences are recorded and made available for later viewing, ensuring continuous access to the learning resources.
By the end of an IOC, companions will be equipped with expertise and confidence to run their own analyses independently.

title: Welcome To the IOC-R Training!
text:
What is IOC?
The InforBio platform has developed an ‚ÄúInteractive Online Companionship‚Äù (IOC) specifically tailored to initiate researchers into bioinformatics. The IOC involved one-to-many virtual work sessions where companions are trained to analyze their own data.
All IOC programs are structured into a series of modules, with each module building upon the knowledge and skills acquired in the previous one. One module lasts one week, during which companions dive into online materials to ensure they understand and internalize the content. Companions then complete quizzes and exercises using both public and their own data to gauge their understanding, receiving personalized feedback on their work. To facilitate their learning, we provide access to computational resources such as Rstudio and Galaxy servers. The module wraps up with a 2.5 hours‚Äô videoconference to recap the week‚Äôs material and address any questions. These videoconferences are recorded and made available for later viewing, ensuring continuous access to the learning resources.
By the end of an IOC, companions will be equipped with expertise and confidence to run their own analyses independently.

title: IOC R Training Information
text:
Syllabus

Session Topics

Session 1: Introduction to R and RStudio

Overview of the R environment
Basic commands and RMarkdown

Session 2: R Objects & Logical Operators (Part 1)

Vectors, lists, matrices
Logical operators and basic data manipulation

Session 3: R Objects & Logical Operators (Part 2)

Data frames and tables

Practical exercises


‚Ä¶ (Complete the rest of the syllabus)



Readings and Resources

Recommended Reading:

R for Data Science by Hadley Wickham and Garrett Grolemund (Link)

CRAN R Documentation

Session-Specific Materials:

Session 1 slides and code: (Link to be added)

Session 2 slides and exercises: (Link to be added)




Slides and Recordings
All sessions will be recorded, and the recordings will be shared here after each session.
- Session 1 Recording: (Link to be added)
- Session 2 Recording: (Link to be added)


Important Notes

Zoom Links: Zoom links for each session will be sent out in advance.

Contact: For questions, please contact [Your Email].

Updates: Keep an eye on this page for updates regarding sessions or materials.

title: IOC-R Week1
text:
Welcome to R!


What is R?
Why learn R?
What do you need?

title: IOC-R Week1
text: Rstudio

title: IOC-R Week1
text:
Rstudio





Script Panel: Write your code here‚Äîit‚Äôs your ‚Äúnotebook‚Äù.
Console: This is where R ‚Äútalks back‚Äù to you (shows results).
Environment/History: Tracks your variables and past commands.
Files/Plots/Packages: For managing your files, viewing graphs, or installing tools.

title: IOC-R Week1
text:
Setting Up Your Project
Tree Structure of a Project: üìÇ My_Project
üìÑ scripts/: Your R code files (e.g., analysis.R). üìÇ data/: Raw data files (e.g., experiment.csv). üìÇ outputs/: Results, graphs, or reports.

title: IOC-R Week1
text:
Getting Started in R
Basic Commands to Try Now:
# Math with R:
2 + 2    # Yes, R can do math!
sqrt(16) # Square root.

# Create a Variable:
x <- 5 # Now x is 5. You can reuse it!

# Inspect Your Environment:
## Look at the top-right panel‚Äîdo you see your x?

# Quit RStudio Properly:
q()

title: IOC-R Week1
text:
Rstudio
Quick Tips:

Run code: Highlight it and press Ctrl + Enter (Windows) or Cmd + Enter (Mac).
Help is your friend: Type ?function_name (e.g., ?mean) for guidance.

title: IOC-R Week1
text:
Slack + Trello (+ github?)
Overview of R programming language and its applications.
Introduction to RStudio (IDE, integrated development environment): setting up the environment, presentation of the functionality of different panels, getting help in R, useful keyboard shortcuts, quitting RStudio.
Show an example of a real project (folder structure), introduce the notion about paths in Linux.
Basic functions: help(), ?, ls(), getwd(), setwd(), length(), dim(), rm(), typeof(), mode(), etc.
File manipulation in R:

file.exists(), file.copy(), dir.create(), basename(), dirname()
Importing data (e.g., .csv, tsv, Excel): upload and read into R, download online data using URL
Exporting results (e.g., csv, Excel, .rds and .RData).

Introduction to Quarto (or RMarkdown) for documenting work.
Catchy example: generate a quick report -> download online data and import it into R, generate descriptive statistics (summary()) and a simple figure (plot()).
Exercise: Get familiar with the RStudio, simple data import/export using the GUI. No extra exercises but need to preview the section of variable types.

Example data (RNAseq): https://monashbioinformaticsplatform.github.io/r-more/r-more-files.zip

title: IOC-R Week1
text:
Setting Up Your Project
Tree Structure of a Project:
- my_project  |- README.md # A short introduction of the project  |- scripts/ # Your R code files (e.g., analysis.R)  |- data/ # Raw data files (e.g., experiment.csv)  |- outputs/ # Results, graphs, or reports
In Linux and Mac system: the separator is ‚Äú/‚Äù In Windows: the separator is ‚Äú\‚Äù

title: IOC-R Week1
text:
Rstudio
Quick Tips:

Run code: Highlight it and press Ctrl + Enter (Windows) or Cmd + Enter (Mac).
Comment/ Uncomment code: Ctrl + Shift + C (Windows) or Cmd + Shift + C (Mac)
Help is your friend: Type function_name in the search box or ?function_name in the console for the documentation.
Check all possible shortcuts: Tools -> Keyboard Shortcuts Help

title: IOC-R Week1
text:
Setting Up Your Project
getwd() # Get working directory
setwd() # Set working directory
Create an R project:

HERE: need a screen shot of creating project on the server, then create the sub folders (scripts, outputs, etc) then show the tree structure
Tree structure:
project_IOC/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md           # A short introduction of the project. 
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ data                # Raw data files (e.g., experiment.csv)
‚îÇ¬†¬† ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ raw_count.tsv
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ scripts             # Your R code files
‚îÇ¬†¬† ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ 01-analysis.R
‚îÇ¬†¬† ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ 02-figures.R
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ outputs             # Results, graphs, or reports 
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 01-analysis.xlsx
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ 02-figures/
Separator: ‚Äú/‚Äù (Linux/Mac) or ‚Äú\‚Äù (Windows)
Example: project_IOC/data/raw_count.tsv

q()

title: IOC-R Week1
text:
Need Some Help?

Google it!
Ask your question via Slack
ChatGPT is your friend ;)

Key points:

explain your question step-by-step
share the context
use keywords
try to rephrase the question



what are you trying to do / what did you try?
the warning or error message / your code / your data structure
language name / function or package name / a specific problem
try and iterate
